Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: An individual arrived at the mosque in visible distress, seeking immediate spiritual counsel to cope with a major loss.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I tried to keep my voice steady as the customer fired off another technical question about our new service. My script only skimmed the surface, and I could sense his frustration growing. I glanced at the clock, knowing my shift was almost over, but my mind was already at the mosque. Just as I was about to transfer the call, my phone buzzed with a message: someone had arrived at the mosque, desperate for guidance after a devastating loss. As an imam, I knew my community expected me to be present, to offer comfort and wisdom in their darkest moments. But as a telemarketer, I was expected to handle every objection, to never leave a call unresolved. My heart pounded as I weighed the needs of a grieving soul against the demands of my job, feeling the tension pull me in two directions at once.
